questions.question: When you read a novel or poem, what do you focus on first?
options: The characters and their development
The plot and what happens in the story
The language, symbolism, and literary techniques used
The themes and underlying messages in the text

questions.question: How do you approach understanding a challenging or abstract piece of literature?
options: I reread the passage multiple times until I can interpret it
I try to get a general sense first and then go back for deeper analysis
I focus on breaking down the words, metaphors, or symbolism
I seek out secondary resources (e.g., analyses, discussions) to help me understand it

questions.question: If a text has multiple possible interpretations, how do you usually engage with it?
options: I try to choose one interpretation and stick with it
I enjoy exploring and discussing different interpretations
I look for concrete evidence in the text to support my interpretation
I leave it open-ended and enjoy thinking about different possibilities

questions.question: When reading a poem, what helps you understand its meaning best?
options: Focusing on the structure, rhyme, and rhythm of the poem
Analyzing the figurative language (metaphors, similes, etc.) and symbolism
Thinking about the emotional impact and tone of the poem
Discussing the poem with others to explore different viewpoints

questions.question: How do you feel about abstract or non-literal poetry?
options: I enjoy it and try to decipher its deeper meanings
I find it challenging but I appreciate the complexity
I struggle to connect with it, preferring more straightforward language
I tend to focus on how the poem makes me feel, rather than finding a specific meaning

questions.question: When analyzing a literary text, what is the most important aspect for you to focus on?
options: The structure and form of the text (e.g., narrative style, point of view)
The themes, messages, or moral lessons of the work
The character development and relationships
The language, literary devices, and stylistic choices made by the author

questions.question: How do you usually identify a literary theme in a text?
options: I look for recurring symbols, words, or motifs
I focus on the actions and experiences of the characters
I consider the overall message the author seems to be communicating
I engage with others to hear their ideas and interpretations of the themes

questions.question: How do you best prepare for a literature exam or essay on a book or poem?
options: I read the book or poem again, paying close attention to key passages and quotes
I summarize each chapter or poem to ensure I understand the main ideas
I make detailed notes about literary devices and themes
I discuss the text with others or attend group study sessions to compare interpretations

questions.question: How do you prefer to take notes when studying a literary text?
options: I write down detailed analyses of the language, form, and style
I jot down summaries and key ideas from each section of the text
I focus on noting down quotes that seem important or thought-provoking
I take bullet points or mind maps that link themes, characters, and key moments

questions.question: Do you find it helpful to understand the historical or cultural context of a text when reading literature?
options: Yes, I think it’s crucial to understand the time period and background of the author
Yes, but only if it directly relates to the themes or characters in the text
I prefer to focus on the text itself, without thinking too much about its context
It’s helpful, but I don’t always engage with the context unless it’s explicitly discussed

questions.question: When studying a piece of literature, how often do you look at literary criticism or analyses of the work?
options: Often—reading what experts think helps me deepen my understanding
Sometimes—if I’m unsure about a part of the text, I’ll check analyses
Rarely—unless I’m struggling to understand a key concept or theme
Never—I prefer to form my own opinions without external influence

questions.question: Which genre of literature do you find most engaging?
options: Novels—especially ones with complex characters and plot twists
Poetry—because of the emotional depth and the challenge of interpretation
Plays—due to the dialogue and performance aspect
Short stories—because of their concise and often thought-provoking nature

questions.question: When reading a literary work that includes multiple genres (e.g., a novel with poems or a play with prose), how do you approach it?
options: I analyze each genre separately to see how they contribute to the work as a whole
I try to understand how the different genres interact and enhance the meaning of the text
I focus on the narrative and themes, regardless of the genre
I pay special attention to how each genre affects the tone or mood of the text
